reviews.review_msg: i will admit readings are heavy at times but he does a great job of explaining concepts. when he teaches topics that may still affect people (ie palestine) he does so in a respectful manner. very kind and wants his students to do well. respects other perspectives and engages participation. i wish all the best for this prof and appreciate his help

Great professor. Get ready to read! If you want to learn about the subject matter take this class. Class discussions are great if everyone participates. You will also write a lot in this class so be ready to engage with the material. The professor is always available if you require advice or knowledge on the material. Great prof if you work hard!

Not the best prof. I disagree that he is caring, and I didn't feel comfortable or confident in class. I don't know if that is because of the group of students, but it made me dread coming to class and tutorials. Though, I enjoyed the topics in the lecture.

Nice professor, cares a lot about students, but absolutely gargantuan weekly readings. Only assignments are usually a few papers, which he grades harshly, but fair. Take classes only if deeply interested on the subject.

The reading you do barely connect with lectures, he goes on tangents and speaks fast so you miss a lot of the information. His tutorials have bad structure and he leaves the room when you talk in groups. His exams are unreasonable in 50 mins he wants a 5 page paper with good grammar, names and dates that covers 150 years plus two other paragraphs

Not a good 1st year prof. Assigns at least 60 pages of reading a week, which wouldn't be terrible if his lectures focused on them. He often goes off on tangents, leaving students feeling lost and confused. His tutorials aren't helpful, just discussions. A very tough marker and his grades aren't subject to negotiation (against school policy).

Great guy, interesting course. Thomas explains the material clearly and the readings are an excellent addition to the broader course content. However, he can mark on the tougher side, and it takes him a long time to respond to your emails and to get papers/exams back to you. Still a solid prof though!

Thomas was terrible. He assumes you have prior knowledge of the course. He was a boring and monotonous lecture. Laughed at his own jokes. Seemed to always be talking to himself at times , he would drone away in low tones. He is a tough marker and not very accessible outside class. Cancelled office hours often. Never take this course !

He's very smart, knowledgable and passionate. However, for an introductory course this may not be an advantage. Sadly, he seemed to assumed we had previous knowledge on middle eastern history and his lectures/content were disorganized. He does not use canvas or even PowerPoint

took a little bit but i got used to him over the semester and actually grew to enjoy his class. He is honestly very helpful when it comes to helping with your term paper which is the big chunk of your grade. He is a difficult marker but your grade seems to get better as the semester goes on. And he took us for beers on the last day, which was great

Dr. Kuehn is an extremely qualified, patient, and passionate professor of history who always takes the time to answer difficult questions and attend to students' needs. He is a pleasure to speak with, inside and outside of class, and although he demands a considerable amount of reading for his courses, the texts he selects are essential reading.

He is very knowledgeable and is often very engaging. Readings were often very difficult, and we had over 120 pages per week to read. He's a real GPA-killer for anyone who can't dedicate an exorbitant amount of time into the course. I did come out learning a lot more than I've learned in any other course though: Learned lots, but grading is hard.

As mentioned before, prof is a walking library on Ottoman history. Even more important, you walk away with some real insights when analyzing sources in the the tutorials. You need to do your readings prior to class to get the most out of this course. Prof has a very nice way of engaging with the class. Highly recommended. One of the best profs!

Expects the class to have previous knowledge of the topic despite no course prerequisites, also expects you have the same level of knowledge as him for the midterm and final. You are required to read an additional textbook to write your paper on. Tough class but doable if you put in the time. Recommended for those with a high interest in the topic.

Take a class from this prof if you want something interesting and moderately challenging. He assigns a lot of reading, but it's all stuff that is worthwhile and he marks fairly. Also, his comments on assignments are generally quite helpful. With appropriate warnings as to reading required, I would definitely recommend.
Avoid like the Black Plague

Must attend lectures - lectures almost the entire time with few breaks. Heavy emphasis on readings, and there are MANY of them every week. Paper is slightly vague. Midterm was straightforward but he is a hard marker. A nice guy though and available for questions/help.

Never again am I going to take his class. Good luck, you're going to need it. He expects students to answer questions but all he response with is ok. Never tells if you are right or wrong. He even sometimes says what you just said after but in a more academic way. I wish someone would have told me about him before I took his class.

Super nice guy.Really cares about students, and appreciates intelligent commentary and debates. He does assign a ton of readings, but only because he himself is so enthusiastic and is like a walking library. Very helpful if you display genuine effort and interest.

I found him to be extremely helpful, open to questions, comments and I took 2 classes with him. It would have been nice to have the exams back sooner but he has no TA. If you don't like or understand middle east/ islamic history then don't take his class:  he presumes prior knowledge as is stated in the syllabus and your ignorance is not his fault.

Very academic guy. Made the subject material inaccessible and kept expectations intentionally vague. Time alloted for tests was short but questions long. He seemed to think he was teaching a graduate course instead of an undergrad one??

There was a lot of material to cover in this course so lectures were crammed with information and it was easy to zone out.  The weekly tutorial questions were okay but sometimes it felt like he was looking for a specific answer to a broad question.  Likes to put big questions that asks for many examples on his exams.

Very strict in both attendance and grading.  Finds it difficult to foster class discussion as he seeks to delve well into the minutia of the subject before most of the class can grasp the more general concepts.  Clearly an expert on Turkey, a nice guy and organizes the lecture subjects well, but besides that I found him a hard marker and too anal.

Very nice person and soft spoken. He helps you if you seek him out and is extremely knowledgeable in his field and speaks like 5 languages, which impresses me. However, he is a very difficult marker and wants you to pretty much write a textbook based on your notes and readings. Oh, and his lectures are very difficult to follow.
Nice guys expects alot but i like his exam style

An over-qualified academic whose failing is that he cannot 'lower' himself to his student's level - he acts as if all his students understand the subject already. His passion is clear, he's generally nice, but his 'help' is often vague and he DOES have quite the temper if irked. Very tough course with a professor of dubious 'teaching' quality.

The hardest professor I have ever had. He's an absolute academic genius, and unfortunately expects you to live up to that kind of standard. Dense, difficult, lengthy readings. Exams which ask you to basically write a research paper from knowledge. Nice guy, but really, he needs to lower himself to his students' level - the problem is that he can't.

He is a hard and demanding prof. Class participation is a "SACRED DUTY." I got around B - B+ in his classes, but I still thought he was a great prof. He tried to take politics out of the class as much as possible and is "all about history" (Said by a classmate) Contrary to other comments, he is no longer late to class nor does he throw "hissy fits"

Kuhn is a good prof, an interesting lecturer, and although he does assign a lot of readings they are usefull for the course.  He definately expects a lot of his students and the midterms/exams are not easy.  Definately learn how to include a lot of detail in your analyses.
boring personality, completely unorganized and all over the place, note taking is close to impossible, would not rec him unless you need to take his course.
He clearly knows his stuff, and is fluent in like 5 languages. He's a freaken hard marker, but a great lecturer. If you don't do your readings however, your screwed :)

I like Kuhn as a person, as professor he's terrible. Completely unprofessional, marking takes forever. As far as studying goes read everything a dozen or so times and then read it again. Never understood what it was he wanted, only what he didn't like after the fact. Don't take him unless you must.

terrible, awful, horrible prof. often late to class (5-20 minutes, w/out explanation). threw a HISSY FIT  over students not doing lecture readings. is a 300-lvl (not 100-lvl survey) prof & ought to be able to lecture w/out students having done readings. poor attitude towards students too. avoid unless course is requisite!

Knows his information, and will tell you everything he knows. Good guy, hard to understand what he wants in seminars. DO THE READING, lost without it. Will go into GREAT detail after every question or input by another class member.
What is it about this guy that he thinks he can show up late to every darned class? No logic to his lectures either.

He was a really nice guy, but was extremely disorganized and very confusing. i found that there was too much information to wrap your mind around important facts. Also, his complusive lateness and lengthy marking periods I found to be unprofessional.
Overall this instructor was not the easiest. His attitude towards the students was poor. Basically the guy is a slacker that wants to do the minimum amount of work for a huge salary

Good guy, very helpful and pleasant to converse with. However, completely disorganized, always, always late and the class notes are half useless. He spends too much time on subjects he enjoys instead of the necessary ones. As well, he falls behind in lectures because he's 5-20 min late every class.

A nice person, and will give a lot of help if you ask for it.  His marking style is a bit strange; extremely hard on essays, but very easy on in-class exams.  His lecture style is disorganized  and confusing, and it is difficult to take notes.  A bit biased as well when it comes to certain issues.
horrible!!!

This prof is grounded in ambiguity- he is not sure whether or not to give equal weight to lectures or readings. He is disorganized, yet extremely intelligent; very rigid and unwilling to give second chances to those who wish to work hard. A great critic for someone willing to take criticism.
Great class great prof. however, i was disappointed that he spent so little time on iran.
I totally thought he was an awesome teacher. I found him really nice, really knowledgable, and his class pretty fair. Marks a little hard.

Thomas definately knows his stuff; although his lectures can be a bit dry. fair marker. Shows up 5-15 minutes late for every class (mind that it was at 8:30am). Also handed back the midterm 6 weeks after we had taken it. Completely middle of the road prof.
Wonderful prof who is extremely knowledgeable and kind. He is always making time to help students by providing extra office hrs during exams. He's got a great sense of humor too!
the prof was not really helpful to students. Expects too much ffom the student. He's a bit arrogant and at times rude.
way too hard and biased

pretty good prof and class, he's a tough marker though, but he knows his material very well, and the lectures are generally pretty interesting. although his lecture style is alittle bit dry, but he's quite helpful and infomative when you ask him questions

Terrific prof. He's a bit nervous, doesn't quite know how to handle students yet (this is only his first year). Knowledgeable, interesting, clear, and a really nice guy. He may cast furtive looks at the door while he's talking to you - learn to love it.

interesting,but difficult course for those who have no background in middle east/ottoman hist.u learn a lot about ottoman+Turkish hist after taking this course. He is able to present material in a logical+clear way u can follow. Nice+kind, just gets angry sometimes. excellect lecturer+expert

I have no doubt that in a few yrs he will be a great prof. He has the knowledge and the passion. Tho he's monotone, bits and pieces of his personality shines thr at times. I've had worst profs. But right now, he sucks. If you don't mind being a guinea pig, then take his classes.
Extremely hard marker, boring lecturer. Very picky and detail oriented.
way too much work, too much to read. very boring, hard to follow in lectures. tutorials a waste of tiime. and hard marker!!
Oh mygawd!!!! focus man!!!!!

Thought provoking reading material and response questions albeit he doesnt lead seminars in the traditional SFU way. He may seem evasive at first but he is extremely helpful and approachable. Came out of the class with a new interest in M/E history. Great Prof!
No Comments
No Comments
Boring Lectures and very unhelpful in general. Didn't answer questions.
Knowledgeable, interesting, and very nice.
No Comments
